conclusion: To determine how the number of molecules colliding with the unit area of the wall per unit time changes from state C to state D in the Stirling cycle, we need to analyze the properties of the gas during the isothermal process C→D.
The process C→D is isothermal, meaning the temperature \( T \) remains constant.
In an isothermal process for an ideal gas, the product of pressure \( P \) and volume \( V \) is constant: \( PV = \text{constant} \).
The number of molecules colliding with the unit area of the wall per unit time is related to the pressure \( P \) and the average speed of the molecules.

premise: Since the process is isothermal, if the volume decreases from C to D, the pressure must increase to maintain \( PV = \text{constant} \).
conclusion: The pressure increases from state C to state D.

The number of collisions per unit area per unit time is proportional to the pressure \( P \) and inversely proportional to the square root of the temperature \( T \) (since the average speed of molecules is proportional to \( \sqrt{T} \)).
Mathematically, the collision frequency \( Z \) can be expressed as: \( Z \propto \frac{P}{\sqrt{T}} \).

premise: Since \( T \) is constant during the isothermal process, \( Z \propto P \).
conclusion: The collision frequency \( Z \) is directly proportional to the pressure \( P \).

premise: As the gas transitions from state C to state D, the volume decreases, leading to an increase in pressure \( P \).
conclusion: The pressure \( P \) increases from C to D.

premise: Because the collision frequency \( Z \) is directly proportional to the pressure \( P \) and \( P \) increases from C to D.
conclusion: The number of molecules colliding with the unit area of the wall per unit time increases from state C to state D.
